description: Learn to design clean, consistent, and usable APIs. Covers naming, error handling, and documentation.

slides.title: Rule #1: Consistency
slides.content:
# Be Predictable üîÆ

If you use `camelCase` for one endpoint, use it for all.

If `POST` returns 201 Created on users, it should return 201 Created on posts.

Predictability = Usability.

slides.title: Naming Conventions
slides.content:
# Plural Nouns üìö

- Good: `/users`, `/products`, `/orders`
- Bad: `/user`, `/product_list`, `/getOrders`

Use nouns to represent resources, and plural nouns generally read better (`GET /users/5` vs `GET /user/5`).

slides.title: URL Structure
slides.content:
# Hierarchy üå≥

Show relationships naturally.

`GET /users/123/orders`

This clearly means "Get the orders belonging to user 123".

Avoid deep nesting. `/users/1/orders/99/items/5` is hard to read. Use `/orders/99/items` instead.

slides.title: Error Handling
slides.content:
# Be Specific üö®

Don't just return 200 OK for everything.

Use proper codes: 400, 401, 403, 404, 500.

Return clear JSON details:
```json
{
  "error": "DuplicateEmail",
  "message": "Email already exists."
}
```

slides.quizQuestion: What is the recommended naming convention for resource endpoints?

slides.title: Versioning
slides.content:
# Future Proofing üîÆ

APIs change. Don't break existing clients.

Version your API from day 1.

- URL: `https://api.com/v1/users` (Most common)
- Header: `Accept-Version: v1`

slides.title: Filtering & Sorting
slides.content:
# Standardize Params üîç

Decide heavily on a convention for filtering.

- `sort=name` vs `sort_by=name`
- `order=asc` vs `sort=+name`
- `limit=10` vs `take=10`

Pick one standard and document it.

slides.title: Documentation
slides.content:
# OpenAPI (Swagger) üìú

The standard for documenting REST APIs.

Write a YAML/JSON file describing endpoints, inputs, and outputs.

Tools generate interactive documentation sites automatically.

slides.title: Partial Responses
slides.content:
# Field Selection ü§è

Allow clients to pick fields to save bandwidth (like GraphQL Lite).

`GET /users?fields=id,name,email`

Google APIs use this pattern heavily.

slides.title: Rate Limiting Headers
slides.content:
# Communicate Limits üõë

Tell the client how many requests they have left.

- `X-RateLimit-Limit`: 100
- `X-RateLimit-Remaining`: 99
- `X-RateLimit-Reset`: 1609459200 (Unix TS)

slides.title: Doc Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which specification is the industry standard for describing REST APIs?

slides.title: Code Example
Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Design üéì

Usability First.

- **Consistency:** Be predictable.
- **Nouns:** `/v1/resources`.
- **Errors:** Use status codes & details.
- **Docs:** OpenAPI/Swagger.
- **Pagination:** Essential for lists.
